I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Improving domestic connectivity is one of the key strategic pillars of the government’s 
National Medium-Term Development Plan (RPJMN), 2010–2014. It is also one of the strategic 
foci of the government’s Master Plan for Acceleration and Expansion of Indonesia’s Economic 
Development (MP3EI), 2011–2025, issued in May 2011. With the aim of achieving higher and 
more inclusive growth across Indonesia, the MP3EI has three strategic foci: (i) accelerating 
economic development in six economic corridors; (ii) improving national connectivity; and (iii) 
strengthening human resources, science, and technology, which are prerequisites to sustained, 
accelerated, and green growth. The new Asian Development Bank (ADB) Country Partnership 
Strategy  2012–2014  currently  being  finalized  has  two  key  pillars—inclusive  growth  and 
environment sustainability. Strategically, the RPJMN provides direction for the new country 
partnership strategy, while the MP3EI will be the convergence of ADB’s sector and thematic 
interventions1 and the government’s vision of accelerated development. The policy and advisory 
technical assistance (TA)2 will support the government initiative on the second strategic focus 
on improving domestic connectivity, with emphasis on interisland connectivity. Recognizing the 
need  to  upgrade  its  capacity  to  support  accelerated  reforms  in  the  area,  the  government 
requested the TA during the country partnership strategy consultation prior to the release of the 
MP3EI. The TA was first included in the ADB TA pipeline in May 2011. The priority areas 
covered under the TA were formulated based on discussion with the Ministry of Transport 
(MOT), the National Development Planning Agency (BAPPENAS), and Coordinating Ministry of 
Economic Affairs (CMEA) during ADB fact-finding and consultation missions. Agreement was 
reached with the government on the impact, outcome, outputs, implementing arrangements, 
cost and financing arrangements, and terms of reference of the TA. The design and monitoring 
framework is in Appendix 1.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Good economic management after the Asian financial crisis restored economic growth to 
an average of 5.1% during 2000–2009. Economic growth in 2010 strengthened further to 6.1% 
supported  by  more  buoyant  investment  and  exports.  However,  significant  development 
challenges remain. Recent economic growth is still significantly below the pre-crisis level and 
the government’s medium-term target of 7%–8% as stated in the RPJMN. While poverty and 
unemployment have trended downward, they remain relatively high. Poverty rates in some 
provinces in eastern Indonesia are higher than elsewhere in the country. The government also 
intends to reduce inflation over the medium term—it is higher and more volatile than in other 
competitor countries and is increasingly an issue that could potentially slow down poverty 
reduction. The major sources of recent inflationary pressure are on the supply side, with a 
visible difference across provinces in the country, suggesting that the solution in the medium 
term has to include improved domestic connectivity.  
 
3.  The  government  recognizes  that  lagging  infrastructure,  underdeveloped  interisland 
connectivity, and an inefficient logistics system are among key constraints on achieving its 
target of higher growth, faster poverty reduction, and lower inflation. Studies have pointed out 
that infrastructure and logistics systems have emerged as a major constraint on accelerating

2   
economic growth in Indonesia.3 The quality of Indonesia's infrastructure and logistics systems is 
lower  than  that  of  its  neighbors,  resulting  in  lower  levels  of  domestic  and  international 
connectivity.  The  recent  success  of  the  country  in  maintaining  a  healthy  macroeconomic 
environment throughout the 2008 global financial crisis has boosted Indonesia’s ranking in 
terms of economic competitiveness by 10 places in the Global Competitiveness Index to 46 in 
2011.4 However, Indonesia’s ranking of 82 on overall quality of infrastructure is far below its 
overall ranking, implying that infrastructure is a drag on the country’s competitiveness. The 
Global Enabling Trade Report ranked Indonesia 75 out of 121 countries in terms of efficiency of 
customs administration and 94 in terms of transparency of border administration in 2009.5 
Clearance at Indonesian ports take a very long time, with about 25% of import containers taking 
more than 10 days to clear. Restrictive regulations result in low competition in the provision of 
logistics services. Logistics costs in Indonesia are estimated at about 14% of total production 
costs, compared to only about 5% in Japan.6 
 
4.  The impact of lagging infrastructure, poor interisland connectivity, and an inefficient 
logistics system has appeared in a number of forms. Sending a 40-foot (12.2 meter) container 
from Jakarta and Surabaya to Bitung (North Sulawesi) costs $600, compared to approximately 
$300 from Jakarta to Singapore, because small domestic container ships cannot capture the 
same economies of scale available to larger vessels. Productivity (in containers moved per hour) 
of the typical crane in Indonesia ports is 40–45 containers while Singapore can achieve 100–
110 containers. According to one estimate, the average turnaround time for domestic shipping 
at the 25 strategic ports is 2.7 days. With average sailing time being 1.5 days, ships were 
spending about 75% of the total time between destinations at port. Due to delays in cargo 
handling, the main shipping lines report that to keep to schedule they often have to leave 
Jakarta port before loading is complete. Reflecting poor logistics and inadequate transport 
infrastructure, about 70% of the rice price differences across provinces is explained by the 
degree of remoteness.7 High interisland freight rates mean availability and prices of basic 
commodities fluctuate widely in remote areas, resulting in higher average inflation in some 
provinces in Indonesia. A bag of cement which costs Rp50,000 in Jakarta or Surabaya (Java) 
will  cost  Rp75,000  in  Jayapura  and  Rp500,000  in  Wamena  (both  in  Papua).  In  addition, 
Indonesia’s manufacturing sector is not well integrated into international production networks 
because of unreliable transport and high logistics costs.  
 
5.  To  help  address  the  challenges,  the  connectivity  pillar  of  the  MP3EI  focuses  on 
(i) improving intra-economic-corridor connectivity by developing roads, shipping, and railways 
and improving local access to the centers of growth and facilities; (ii) improving inter-economic-
corridor connectivity by developing good interconnection between primary ports and airports 
(especially in eastern Indonesia) and reducing logistics and economic costs of intercorridor 
delivery of goods and services; and (iii) improving international trade logistics by developing 
ports  and  airports  as  international  hubs  in  western  and  eastern  Indonesia,  optimizing  the 
operation of customs, and improving the operation of international ports and airports through

implementation  of  an  integrated  logistics  system.  After  the  issuance  of  the  MP3EI,  the 
government revisit, harmonize, synergize, and update its existing planning documents, such as 
the National Logistics System and the National Transportation System. The updates will be 
reflected in the annual implementation plan of connectivity programs. This exercise can be 
strengthened  significantly  with  updated  information,  particularly  on  inter-economic-corridor 
connectivity.  
 
6.  Connecting less-developed eastern Indonesia to domestic and international markets will 
improve  access  to  goods  and  services  at  lower,  more  stable  prices,  as  well  as  increase 
production and the volume of domestic and international trade by lowering transaction costs. In 
addition, improved connectivity will (i) support greater integration between provinces to reduce 
price volatility resulting from the impact of sudden shocks in production or demand; (ii) increase 
market access as well as the competitiveness of Indonesian goods, including those from the 
eastern  part  of  the country;  and  (iii)  contribute  to  greater  diversification  in  production  and 
exports  while  encouraging  domestic  rather  than  foreign  commodity  processing,  thereby 
increasing employment and reducing poverty. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
7.  The  impact  will  be  to  enhance  implementation  of  reforms  to  improve  interisland 
connectivity. The outcome will be the strengthened analytical capacity of the MOT, BAPPENAS, 
and CMEA to deliver policy analysis on domestic connectivity to support their annual planning 
and strategy.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
8.  The TA will provide inputs to the review and updating process of government planning 
documents by developing basic databases, key performance indicators, and selected analysis 
of interisland connectivity constraints. The TA will cover four core areas:  
(i)  reviewing the existing planning documents and related regulations and doing a 
stock take of recent studies and relevant international experience;  
(ii)  conducting a logistics chain survey of three key commodities on four origin–
destination pairs for each to establish initial case study data and to identify key 
constraints on efficient interisland connectivity;  
(iii)  developing tools to assess policy and reform options and physical programs to 
address the most critical constraints; and  
(iv)  developing a capacity building program in the MOT and BAPPENAS.  
 
9.  Reviewing documents and stocktaking of studies. The TA will review the existing 
planning documents (such as the National Logistics System and the National Transportation 
System) and related regulations. The TA will also review findings of recent studies and surveys 
related to interisland connectivity and logistics in Indonesia. Recently, the Australian Agency for 
International Development proposed better practice and a number of key institutional reforms to 
improve the implementation of public service obligations. The World Bank is conducting a study 
on the eastern part of Indonesia covering (i) logistics chain analysis to identify market access 
constraints, (ii) capacity and performance of ports along major routes in eastern Indonesia, and 
(iii) feasible ways to use performance-based contracting to improve competition. The Japan 
International  Cooperation  Agency  has  also  been  involved  in  studies  related  to  interisland 
transport. These sources will be complemented by periodic review on economic development

4   
across provinces in Indonesia conducted by Bank Indonesia. The TA will also review relevant 
international  experience,  including  from  Japan  and  the  Philippines’  experience  related  to 
nautical highway development and institutional reforms, to demonstrate the benefits of similar 
reforms to improve intercorridor connectivity.  
 
10.  Conducting a logistics chain survey. The TA will support a logistics chain survey of 
key priority commodities listed in the MP3EI on four origin–destination pairs for each to establish 
initial case study data and to identify key constraints on efficient interisland connectivity. The 
surveys will (i) estimate inter-province trade and passenger services in two selected areas, one 
in western Indonesia and one in eastern Indonesia;8 (ii) collect data needed to develop costs 
and the determinants of the cost structure across logistics systems to help define areas that 
need clear policy intervention and physical investment; and (iii) cover interconnection between 
modes of transport—shipping, road transport, and railway. The information collected from the 
survey will also be used to develop initial key performance indicators for ports, airports, and 
logistics providers. The survey will also help assess other impediments to domestic connectivity, 
including institutional, regulatory, and physical impediments. 
 
11.  Assessing policy options and physical programs. The principal output of the TA will 
be assessment of selected policy options and investment programs that the government may 
undertake  to  address  the  constraints.  After  completion  of  the  review  and  the  survey,  the 
potential policy and investment options will be analyzed using an applied economy-wide general 
equilibrium economic model and other tools. The model will have appropriate desegregation for 
provinces in the country as well as a detailed poverty module to capture the impacts—both 
economic  and  poverty  related—of  the  policy  reform  and  investment  programs,  leading  to 
improved  intercorridor  connectivity  and  domestic  logistics  systems.  In  the  case  of  eastern 
Indonesia, minimum service standards will need to be established for shipping and air transport, 
as well as port access and service standards for both passengers and freight. Under the TA, 
comprehensive  analyses  for  selected  cases  will  be  developed  to  identify  policies  and 
institutional arrangements to achieve minimum service, infrastructure, and efficiency standards. 
 
12.  Building capacity. The TA will include a capacity development program for the MOT, 
BAPPENAS, and related government agencies. Staff from these agencies will participate in all 
TA activities. Around 20–30 staff will be trained in economic model and impact assessment 
analysis. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
13.  The TA is estimated to cost $500,000 equivalent. It will be financed on a grant basis by 
the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction, and administered by ADB. The government will provide 
counterpart  support  through  the  provision  of  office  space,  office  communications,  and 
remuneration and per diem for counterpart staff. Details of the cost estimates and financing plan 
are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
14.  The TA will be implemented over 23 months, from 15 January 2012 to 15 December 
2013. The MOT will be the executing agency. The MOT, CMEA and BAPPENAS will be the 
implementing agencies. The MOT will establish and chair the TA steering committee. The 
steering committee will convene as needed, and be regularly consulted on implementation of TA 
                                                 
8  Interisland transport systems are characterized by congestion in the west and lack of traffic in the east.

5
activities. The MOT will ensure that key stakeholders participate in surveys and stakeholder 
consultations.  These  stakeholders  include  relevant  state  enterprises,  transport  operator 
associations, and industry associations. The MOT, CMEA and BAPPENAS will ensure that 
government counterpart staff members participate in capacity building and other TA activities. 
The TA consultants will administer workshops, training, seminars, conferences, and surveys.  
 
15.  In consultation with the MOT, ADB will recruit consultants as required under the TA (17 
person-months of consulting services, consisting of one international consultant for 5 person-
months and two national consultants for a total of 12 person-months). The team of consultants, 
led  by  the  international  consultant,  will  be  responsible  for  producing  the  TA  outputs  and 
deliverables  in  a  timely  and  effective  manner,  and  for  organizing  and  carrying  out  all  TA 
activities.  The  consultants’  terms  of  reference  are  in  Appendix  3.  The  consultants  will  be 
selected and engaged on an individual basis by ADB in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on 
the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time).9 Consultants will be chosen 
based on their academic qualifications and relevant work experience. The proceeds of the TA 
will be disbursed in accordance with the Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, 
as amended from time to time). All procurement under the TA will be carried out in accordance 
with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time).  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
16.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 to the Government 
of Indonesia to be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction for 
Improving Domestic Connectivity, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  A  total  of  17  person-months  of  individual  consulting  services,  consisting  of  one 
international consultant for 5-person months and two national consultants for a total of 12 
person-months, will be required to implement the technical assistance (TA) activities. The team 
of  consultants  will  work  together  to  support  the  government’s  effort  to  improve  interisland 
connectivity. More specifically, the team is expected to deliver (i) targeted analysis of existing 
regulatory and policy frameworks affecting shipping and the interisland connectivity value chain 
in selected locations, (ii) a more empirical-based formulation of recommended policy changes to 
rectify  current  inefficiencies,  (iii)  more  informed  stakeholders  (from  both  public and  private 
sectors)  on  the  priority  reforms  and  their  economic  benefits;  and  (iv)  a  more  synergetic 
approach to addressing interisland connectivity issues by supporting multimodal and different 
solutions  for  different  parts  of  the  country.  All  consultants  should  have  at  least  10  years 
experience in  their  respective  field.  Experience  and  familiarity  with  public sector  reform  in 
Indonesia is required. 
 
1.  International Senior Transport Specialist and Team Leader (intermittent, 5 person-
months) 
 
2.  The international transport specialist will have extensive experience in transport planning, 
logistics,  transport  costing,  policy  analysis,  and  institutional  analysis  and  structuring.  The 
specialist  will  have  experience  working  in  the  Indonesian  transport  sector  or  comparable 
experience in other areas with similar characteristics. As a team leader, the specialist should 
have demonstrated experience in running multidisciplinary teams and developing case studies 
based on surveys and primary data collection. Ability to speak Bahasa Indonesia will be an 
advantage. The specific activities to be carried out by the team leader are as follows: 
(i)  Conduct a comprehensive review of the background documents with the other 
national consultants and prepare an annotated summary of those documents that 
highlight their key findings and recommendations.  
(ii)  Prepare analytical paper 1 to summarize the information in (i) and present it to 
the working group and other invited participants for review and comment at a 
workshop.  
(iii)  With the Asian Development Bank (ADB) project officer, prepare the design and 
terms of reference for the supply chain and logistics survey to be conducted by 
an Indonesian research institution to be selected on a competitive basis. 
(iv)  Participate  in  the  survey  interviews  on  sample  bases  to  obtain  good 
understanding of the responses of the survey participants and to identify any 
emerging issues that were not anticipated in the original design.  
(v)  Prepare analytical paper 2 based on the survey results and present it for review 
by the working group and the participants at the subsequent workshop.  
(vi)  With the national transport specialist and economist, carry out the qualitative and 
quantitative analysis of logistics chain analysis including the cost of handling, 
delay, damage in transit, inventory cost, and direct fees and charges, and carry 
out a sensitivity analysis to determine the potential for largest economic benefit 
from policy options or physical improvements to address the most important 
impediments.  
(vii)  Based on the above analysis, define practical government policies to address 
both the nonphysical barriers as well as the physical impediments to efficient 
interisland  logistics  service.  Review  the  work  of  the  economist  to  link  the 
economic impacts and costs and benefits to the potential institutional implications 
of the policies.

2.  National  Transport  Specialist  and  Deputy  Team  Leader  (intermittent,  6  person-
months) 
 
3.  The national transport specialist should have (i) a broad background in transport policy 
development and logistics analysis in Indonesia, (ii) experience across the range of transport 
modes in Indonesia, and (iii) participated in transport logistics analysis. As deputy team leader, 
the specialist will take primary responsibility for the following activities:  
(i)  Work with the team leader to conduct a comprehensive review of the background 
literature and prepare an annotated summary of those documents that highlights 
their key findings and recommendations. 
(ii)  Work with the team leader to prepare analytical paper 1 and to present it to the 
working  group  and  other  invited  participants  for  review  and  comment  at  a 
workshop.  
(iii)  Work with the team leader to prepare the design and terms of reference for the 
supply chain and logistics survey.  
(iv)  Participate with the survey team in selected interviews and meetings to support 
the preparation of the case study survey log.  
(v)  Work with the team leader to prepare analytical paper 2 to summarize the results 
of the case studies. 
(vi)  Work with the national economist to assess the implications of the proposed 
policies  and  physical  investments  needed  to  overcome  the  identified 
impediments to efficient interisland logistics.  
(vii)  Support the team leader in preparing analytical paper 3 and the materials for the 
subsequent workshop. Participate in the workshop with the other members of the 
team and support preparation of the draft final report and the final report. 
(viii)  Be responsible for the project components that are carried out in the Bahasa 
Indonesia language. This will include, e.g., the review of any required Indonesian 
literature and organization and management of the workshops. 
(ix)  Develop and deliver training programs requested by the relevant government 
agencies. 
 
3.  National Economist (intermittent, 6 person-months) 
 
4.  The national economist should have a strong background in quantitative economics and 
general economic modeling. The economist should have extensive experience in analyzing the

Appendix 3  11 
impact  of  economic  reforms.  Experience  with  economic  analysis  of  transport  and  logistics 
reforms will be an asset. The economist will take primary responsibility for the following activities: 
(i)  Develop an economy-wide model that can be used to analyze the impact of 
improved connectivity on both the provincial and national economies. The model 
should  have  sufficient  province  dimensions  as  well  as  a  detailed  module  to 
assess the poverty implications of the reform options analyzed. 
(ii)  Update  the  model  using  the  latest  provincial  inputs  output  table,  social 
accounting matrix, and other poverty-related survey data. 
(iii)  Work with the team leader to conduct a comprehensive review of the background 
literature and prepare an annotated summary of those documents that highlights 
their key findings and recommendations. 
(iv)  Work with the team leader to prepare analytical paper 1 and to present it to the 
working  group  and  other  invited  participants  for  review  and  comment  at  a 
workshop. 
(v)  Assist the team leader to design the transport and logistics survey as required for 
the economic modeling and impact analysis. 
(vi)  Participate with the survey team in selected interviews and meetings to support 
the preparation of the case study survey log. Identify any emerging issues that 
were not anticipated in the original survey design. 
(vii)  Work with the team leader to prepare analytical paper 2 to summarize the results 
of  the  case  studies  and  integrate  the  finding  into  the  economic  modeling 
exercises. 
(viii)  Work with the team leader and the deputy team leader to assess the implications 
of  the  proposed  policies  and  physical  investments  needed  to  overcome  the 
identified impediments to efficient interisland logistics.  
(ix)  Summarize both the qualitative and quantitative implications of those policies, 
and the costs and benefits to both the broader Indonesian economy and to the 
specific subnational economies that will be directly affected by those policies or 
physical investments.  
(x)  Work with the team leader and the deputy team leader to prepare analytical 
paper  3  and  the  materials  for  the  subsequent  workshop.  Participate  in  the 
workshop with the other members of the team and support preparation of the 
draft final report and the final report. 
(xi)  Develop  and  deliver  training  programs  to  government  officials  related  to  the 
economic modeling and sensitivity analysis used to develop analytical papers. 
(xii)  Assist the team leader in the administration and procurement of workshops, 
training, seminars, equipments, and surveys required under the TA.
